question: The term universal tumor refers to:
exp: Lipomas are most common SUBCUTANEOUS LIPOMAS Also known as UNIVERSAL TUMOUR MC site: Trunk BRACKET CALCIFICATION is seen in lipoma of corpus callosum SURGICAL EXCISION is required for removal

question: Lipoma becomes malignant commonly at which site:
exp: RETROPERITONEAL LIPOMA These swellings sometimes reach an immense size Retroperitoneal lipoma is often malignant (liposarcoma) and may increase rapidly in size A retroperitoneal lipoma sometimes undergoes myxomatous degeneration Clinical Features Swelling or indefinite abdominal pain More common in women Diagnosis Diagnosis is usually by ultrasound and CT scanning.

question: In pigmented basal cell carcinoma, treatment of choice is:
exp: Treatment of Melanoma * Non-aggressive tumor on trunk or extremities: Excision or electrodissection & curettage * Large, aggressive, located at vital areas or recurrent: Moh's micrographic surgery

question: Bowen's disease is:
exp: This is an SCC, of which 3-11% progress to SCC Etiological agents: Chronic solar damage, inorganic arsenic & HPV 16 This is rare, slow-growing intraepidermal SCC that often mimics a chronic dermatosis CLINICAL FEATURES It usually presents with pruritus & on examination looks like psoriasis or senile keratosis. Presents as a slowly enlarging, erythematous, scaly patch or plaque

question: The most malignant form of malignant melanoma is:
exp: Types of Malignant Melanoma *Superficial spreading: MC type of MM; MC site is Torso. *Nodular: 2nd MC type* Most malignant* Only veical growth phase* MC site - Head and Neck *Lentigo maligna: Least malignant; MC site is Face *Acral lentiginous: Least common, worst prognosis. MC site: Sole, under great toe nail Only FDA approved adjuvant therapy for malignant melanoma -Interferon alpha 2b

question: Thiersch graft is which type of graft?
exp: Paial Thickness (Thiersch) or Split Skin Graft Consist of epidermis and variable poion of dermisQ Large size graft can be takenQ Site: Thigh (MC)Q upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm and abdominal wall Grafts are hairless and do not sweatQ (these structures are not transferred) MC causes of skin graft failure: Hematoma (or seroma), infection, and movement (shear). = Wolfe is a type of full thickness graft.

question: Common features of melanoma, which of the following is not the pa of mnemonic ABCDE?
exp: Malignant Melanoma (Mnemonic ABCDE refers to): A- Asymmetry B- Border irregularity C- Color variation D- Diameter >6mm E- Evolving

question: Moh's micrographic excision for basal cell carcinoma is used for all of the following except:
exp: Treatment of Melanoma Non-aggressive tumor on trunk or extremities: Excision or electrodissection & curettage Large, aggressive, located at vital areas or recurrent: Moh's micrographic surgery
opb: Tumor less than 2 cm in diameter

question: Worst prognosis in melanoma is seen in the suptype:
exp: Types of Malignant Melanoma Superficial spreading: MC type of MM; MC site is Torso Nodular: Most malignant; MC site is face Lentigo maligna: Least malignant; MC site is Face Acral lentiginous: Least common, worst prognosis. MC site: Sole, under great toe nail

question: Manchot, salmon, Taylor names are related to:-
exp: Manchot, salmon, Taylor names are related to Aerial supply to the skin flaps Manchot studied skin territories in 1889. Salmon expanded this in 1930s, and Taylor and Palmer developed the angiosome concept in 1987.* ANGIOSOME: The angiosome concept was derived from plastic surgery for the purpose of healing of skin flaps. An angiosome is an anatomic unit of tissue (consisting of skin, subcutaneous tissue, fascia, muscle, and bone) fed by a source aery and drained by specific veins.
opb: Aerial supply to the skin flaps

question: Who said: "Skin is the best dressing?
exp: Joseph lister said "skin is the best dressing".

question: Neuromuscular preserving flap in lip:-
exp: Neuromuscular preserving flap in lip is Karpandzic flap. LIP RECONSTRUCTION Cross-lip Flaps Circumoral Advancement Flaps Lip-Switch (Abbe-Estlander) flapQ used to repair defects of either upper or lower lip, based on superior labial aeryQ Karapandzic flapQ: Uses a sensate, neuromuscular flap based on labial aeryQ. Webster-Bernard repairQ: Use lateral nasolabial flap with buccal advancement

question: All of the following are markers of melanoma except:-
exp: Markers of melanoma are S-100, HMB-45, Vimentin.

question: First line treatment for keloid is:-
exp: Treatment of hyperophic and keloid scars Pressure: local molds or elasticated garments Intralesional steroid injection Excision and postoperative radiation Intralesional excision Laser: To reduce redness Vitamin E or palm oil massage Silicone gel sheeting Excision and steroid injection

question: Which of these scoring systems is helpful in assessing severity of wound infection and is used for research and surveillance?
exp: - Commonly using grading system: Southampton grading scale Asepsis score Southampton Wound Grading System 0: Normal healing Ia: Some bruising Ib: Considerable brusing Ic: Mild erythema I: Normal healing with mild bruising or erythema IIa: At one point IIb: Around sutures IIc: Along wound IId: Around wound II: Erythema plus other signs of inflammation IIIa: At one point only (<2cm) IIIb: Along wound (> 2 cm) IIIc: Large volume IIId: prolonged (>3 days) IV: Pus IVa: At one point only (<2 cm) IVb: Along wound (>2cm)

question: Cylindroma is:
exp: Cylindroma A malignant epithelial tumour also known as Turban tumor Known as cylindroma because of histological appearance

question: Following a small-bowel resection, a 49 years old male develops fever and anemia. The surface surrounding the surgical wound is warm to the touch and necrotizing fasciitis is suspected. Another manifestation that would most suggest necrotizing fasciitis is:
exp: Severe pressure like pain out of propoion to visible signs distinguishes necrotizing fasciitis from cellulitis. Erythema, leukocytosis, and swelling are present in both cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis.

question: Treatment of choice for melanoma is:
exp: Treatment Surgical excision with Sentinel lymph node biopsy Margins to be taken depends on the tumor thickness and depth of invasion * < 1mm thickness - 1 cm margin * 1-4 mm thickness - 2cm margin * > 4mm thickness - 2-3 cm margin Malignant Melanoma is a radio resistant tumor *

question: Diagnostic procedure for basal cell carcinoma:
exp: Diagnostic procedure for BCC is wedge biopsy

question: Myocutaneous flap includes which tissues?
exp: Axial flap is also known as myocutaneous flap- - It is based on a named vessel. -Provide a reproducible & stable skin or skin-muscle flap including Skin, muscle and vascular pedicle. -Can be used to provide much needed length & bulk. -Axial flap that remains attached to its proximal blood supply & transposed to a defect is known as a pedicled flap.

question: The following statement about this condition is true:
exp: The given condition is keloid. Keloid- Has Excessive scar tissue- Scar extends beyond the boundaries of original wound or incision - Etiology - Unknown- Associated with* Elevated levels of growth factors* Deeply pigmented skin* Genetic predisposition* Areas of body where there is increased risk of keloid formation- Above clavicle- Upper extremities- Trunk & Face- Especially seen in the Triangular region with boundaries of Each shouldertip and Xiphisternum - On Histology* Excess collagen & Hypervascularity* Contains disorganized Type I & III collagen* Contains thicker collagen bundles - causes formation of acellular node like structures* Rarely regresses with time* Often refractory to Medical & Surgical intervention - Treatment* First line treatment - Silicones + Pressure therapy + Intralesional injection of triamcinolone * In Refractory Cases (No improvement after 12 months of treatment) - Excision + Post-operative Radiotherapy (External beam radiotherapy / Brachytherapy)
opa: Elevated levels of growth factor is not seen
opb: Extended excision is the treatment of choice
opc: It do not extend beyond the wound
opd: It will have more collagen and vascularity

question: Which of the following insufflation gases should not be used with radiofrequency (RF) electrosurgery?
exp: CO2 is the most commonly used gas for peritoneal insufflation, but alternative gases are available. Nitrous oxide has been used for procedures performed under local anesthesia because it does not cause the acid-base disturbances associated with CO2 pneumoperitoneum and may cause less postoperative pain. However, it suppos combustion, and its use is not recommended in procedures that require RF electrosurgery. Use of ine gases, such as helium and argon, also prevents acid-base problems; however, these agents are rarely used because they are expensive and have low solubility, which may increase the risk for gas embolism.

question: Operation theatre fire is most commonly due to:-
exp: ECRI's analysis of case repos show that the most common ignition sources are electrosurgical instruments (68%) & lasers(13%). Most common fire location is airway(35%), head or face(28%), & elsewhere on or inside the patient (38%). An oxygen enriched atmostphere was a contribution factor in (74%) of all cases.

question: In the Clarke's level of tumor invasion of malignant melanoma level 3 refers to:
exp: Clark's level ( on the basis of depth of invasion): EPIRS 1. Melanoma restricting to epidermis & appendages 2. Invading Papillary dermis without filling it 3. Reach Interface of papillary & reticular dermis 4. Invading reticular dermis 5. Invading subcutaneous tissue.
opa: All tumor cells above basement membrane
opc: Invasion into loose connective tissue of papillary dermis
opd: Tumors cell at junction of papillary and reticular dermis

question: Split skin grafts in young children should be harvested from:
exp: Paial Thickness (Thiersch) or Split Skin Graft Consist of epidermis and variable poion of dermisQ Site: Thigh (MC)Q upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm and abdominal wall Grafts are hairless and do not sweatQ (these structures are not transferred) MC causes of skin graft failure: Hematoma (or seroma), infection, and movement (shear).

question: Within 48 hours of transplantation, skin graft survives due to:
exp: Graft survives upto first 48hrs because of plasma imbibition. Involves free absorption of nutrients into the graft. Inosculation is completed by 4-5 days Revascularization occurs after 5 days

question: Split thickness skin graft is not taken up by:-
exp: For skin graft to get accepted - the recipient bed should be vascularized For avascular places like bone, tendon, etc. - flap is used * Pedicel Graft or Flap Flap: Paially or completely isolated segment of tissue with its own blood supply Absolute Indications for Flaps Exposed bone Radiated vessel Brain Open joint or non-biological implant materials Pressure sores at bony prominences Full-thickness graft/Wolfe's Graft: - Consists of epidermis + full thickness of dermis. Only small graft can be taken For critical and small areas such as an eyelid, a full thickness graft is selected, so that contraction of the grafted material is minimum. Composite graft: Is a graft that contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the donor site, it can contain subcutaneous fat, cailage, and even muscle. It is ideal for repair of deeper defects. Free Flap: - It involves autogenous transplant of vascularised tissues. There is devascularization from donor site & revascularization at recipient bed.

question: Which of the following incision is preferred to excise a lesion on the bridge of the nose?
exp: Any lesion on the bridge of the nose is excised with a horizontal incision because Langer's lines are horizontal on the bridge of the nose Langer's lines represent the orientation of the dermal collagen fibres and any incision placed parallel to these lines results in a better scar

question: Characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma is:
exp: Characteristic features of basal cell carcinoma are: Low grade malignancy. More common in fair & dry skinned people. NUCLEAR PALISADING on histology. Exposure to sunlight is an impoant etiological factor. Has been seen following prolonged administration of Arsenic.

question: Which of the following is true about Marjolin's ulcer?
exp: Marjolin's ulcer may develop in: 1. Post burn scar 2. Chronically discharging osteomyelitis sinus 3. Long standing venous ulcer 4. Chronic ulcer due to trauma 5. Post radiation ulcer Characteristic features Slow growing as scar tissue is relatively avascular. Painless as there is no nerve in the scar tissue. No secondary deposits in the regional lymph node, as there is no lymphatic spread. Radioresistant due to avascularity. If ulcer invades the normal tissue, then only lymph node may be involved by lymphatic spread.

question: Best method to treat large po-wine hemangiomas:-
exp: Selective photothermolysis or pulsed eye laser is the treatment of choice for Po Wine hemangioma. Excellent results have been obtained with careful and time-consuming treatment with a 585-nm flashlamp-pumped pulsed eye laser. Treatment sessions can begin in babies and anesthesia is not always necessary.

question: The best results in treatment of capillary nevus have been achieved by:
exp: Best cosmetic results obtained by Laser ablation.

question: A 3-6 cm scalp defect is closed by:-
exp: Flap: Paially or complete isolated segment of the tissue with its own blood supply Absolute indications for flaps- -exposed bone -radiated vessel -exposed brain -open joint or non- biological implant materials -pressure sores at bony prominences

question: Skin grafting is not contraindicated in?
exp: Skin grafting is absolutely contraindicated in Streptococcal infection because split thickness skin graft is destroyed by these organisms. It is C/I in infections, seroma, cellulitis Well approximated edges of wound - Indication for skin grafting

question: What is the most common type of this malignancy?
exp: Lesion in the given image- Pearly white nodules in the periphery with central umbilication and telangiectatic vessels- BCC Basal Cell Carcinoma: Also called as Rodent ulcer or Tear cancer, Locally Malignant which is slow growing Types of Rodent ulcers are: 1. Nodular (90%) 2. Pigmented 3. Cystic 4. Superficial - MC type -Nodular which has characteristic pearly white nodules in the periphery with central umbilication and telangiectatic vessels.
